ground_truth: Gandhi has remained seated, pensive, while Charlie studies him for a moment. A little grin appears on Gandhi's face, but his mood stays pensive and remote. Gandhi looks up with anger and determination, which is then broken by a hopeless sigh, leaving Charlie stunned and obviously hurt. Gandhi proceeds more gently, and now Charlie understands. Gandhi smiles, showing warmth and sadness, then speaks with determined purposefulness and a friend's trust. He has taken some scratched notes from under the bedding and handed them to Charlie. He nods, meeting Charlie's eyes with a smile that shelters his vulnerability and returns his love. The very English, very steadfast Charlie fights to contain his emotions. The courtroom is packed to overflowing and restless as Gandhi sits in the dock. The English magistrate surveys the courtroom and signals his English clerk to him. The magistrate frowns, seeing the front row from his point of view with two or three Indian journalists and one European, which he receives with some alarm, and he indicates that the clerk take his place. Gandhi stands, and the courtroom is silent, but the sound of chanting outside is still audible. The magistrate stares as the journalists write and the clerk swallows. The magistrate is only too aware of the mob outside as he looks around the courtroom. The clerk lowers his eyes to his pad. The magistrate searches the distant wall, the top of his desk, and his twitching hands for an answer, then stares again, along with the journalists. The magistrate wets his lips, and the court explodes into chaos with cheering and delight. The magistrate rises, looks around the room, and heads for his chambers as the journalists scribble furiously. Gandhi turns and starts out of the courtroom, steps down from the courtroom to the balcony, and a huge cheer comes up from the massed peasants below. As he smiles down at them, he is turned by surprise and caution, followed by even more caution on hearing something that sounds casually ironic but is determined, even angry. Inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, with a portrait of the King prominent behind him, feels cornered for different reasons while the desk is arrayed with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner. He taps one of the folders irritably with his hand as Sir George looks at him, half defensive and half defiant. They are old friends from the same school and social class who have been together a long time in India, arguing as friends who accept the same premises, although the Governor feels the game has not been played quite fairly.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution
test_cases.description: Gandhi has remained seated, contemplative, while Charlie examines him for a moment. A little smile appears on Gandhi's visage, but his temperament stays thoughtful and distant. Gandhi glances up with rage and resolve, which is then disrupted by a despairing exhale, leaving Charlie astonished and visibly wounded. Gandhi continues more tenderly, and now Charlie comprehends. Gandhi beams, displaying warmth and melancholy, then articulates with resolved intentionality and a companion's confidence. He has taken some scratched notes from beneath the bedding and passed them to Charlie. He nods, meeting Charlie's gaze with a grin that shields his vulnerability and reciprocates his affection. The very British, very steadfast Charlie struggles to restrain his feelings. The courtroom is filled to overflowing and uneasy as Gandhi sits in the dock. The British magistrate examines the courtroom and signals his British clerk to him. The magistrate scowls, perceiving the front row from his vantage point with two or three Indian correspondents and one European, which he receives with some dismay, and he indicates that the clerk assume his position. Gandhi rises, and the courtroom is silent, but the noise of hymning outside is still perceivable. The magistrate gazes as the correspondents jot and the clerk gulps. The magistrate is only too conscious of the throng outside as he glances around the courtroom. The clerk lowers his eyes to his pad. The magistrate scrutinizes the distant barrier, the top of his desk, and his twitching hands for a solution, then gazes again, along with the correspondents. The magistrate moistens his lips, and the court erupts into mayhem with acclaim and jubilation. The magistrate elevates, looks around the chamber, and heads for his offices as the correspondents jot rapidly. Gandhi turns and commences out of the courtroom, descends from the courtroom to the terrace, and a vast cheer rises from the assembled villagers below. As he grins down at them, he is turned by astonishment and wariness, followed by even more wariness on hearing something that sounds casually sarcastic but is resolved, even irate. Inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, with a depiction of the King prominent behind him, feels trapped for different reasons while the desk is arrayed with several tall piles of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner. He taps one of the folders angrily with his hand as Sir George observes him, half defensive and half defiant. They are old companions from the same institution and social class who have been together a long time in India, debating as companions who accept the same assumptions, although the Governor feels the contest has not been played quite fairly.

test_cases.name: Active <-> Passive Transformation
test_cases.description: Gandhi has been seated, pensive, while he is studied by Charlie for a moment. A little grin is shown on Gandhi's face, but his mood remains pensive and remote. Gandhi’s expression of anger and determination is looked up at by him, which Gandhi then breaks with a hopeless sigh, leaving Charlie stunned and obviously hurt. A gentler approach is taken by Gandhi, and now understanding is reached by Charlie. Warmth and sadness are shown by Gandhi as he smiles, then he speaks with determined purposefulness and a friend's trust. Some scratched notes have been taken by him from under the bedding and are handed to Charlie. Gandhi nods, and Charlie’s eyes are met by him with a smile that shelters his vulnerability and returns his love. The very English, very steadfast Charlie is fought by himself to contain his emotions. The courtroom has been packed to overflowing and restless as the dock seats Gandhi. The courtroom is surveyed by the English magistrate and his English clerk is signaled to him. The front row is frowned at by the magistrate as he sees, from his point of view, two or three Indian journalists and one European, which receives him with some alarm, and he indicates his clerk to take his place. Gandhi stands, and silence covers the courtroom, but chanting is still audible outside. The journalists are stared at by the magistrate as they write and the clerk swallows. The mob outside is only too aware of the magistrate as he looks around the courtroom. The pad is lowered to by the clerk. An answer is searched for by the magistrate in the distant wall, the top of his desk, and his twitching hands, then the journalists are stared at again by him. His lips are wetted by the magistrate, and cheering and delight explode the court into chaos. The room is looked around by the magistrate as he rises and heads for his chambers as furious scribbling is done by the journalists. Gandhi turns and exits the courtroom, steps down from the courtroom to the balcony, and a huge cheer is raised by the massed peasants below. As down at them he smiles, surprise and caution are turned by him, followed by more caution upon hearing something that sounds casually ironic but is determined, even angry. Inside, different reasons corner Sir Edward Gait, the Governor, with a portrait of the King prominent behind him, while several tall stacks of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner array the desk. One of the folders is tapped irritably by him with his hand as Sir George looks at him, half defensive and half defiant. They, as old friends from the same school and social class, have shared a long time together in India, arguing as friends who accept the same premises, although quite fairly, the game has not been played, feels the Governor.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits pensively while Charlie briefly observes him. A small grin crosses Gandhi's face, but he remains distant. Anger and determination flash in Gandhi's eyes before a hopeless sigh leaves Charlie stunned and hurt. Gandhi softens, and Charlie gains understanding. Gandhi smiles warmly yet sadly, speaking with purpose and trust as he hands Charlie some scratched notes. He nods at Charlie with a smile that hides vulnerability and conveys love. Charlie, very English and steadfast, fights to contain his emotions. The packed courtroom is restless with Gandhi in the dock. The English magistrate notices Indian and European journalists in the front row, alarming him, and directs his clerk to the stand. Gandhi rises to silence, but chanting outside persists. The magistrate, aware of the mob outside, appears anxious, the clerk lowers his gaze, and journalists write. The magistrate stares at his twitching hands for answers, then chaos erupts with cheering. He leaves for his chambers as journalists scribble. Gandhi exits the courtroom to a balcony, greeted by cheering peasants below. Smiling down, he hears something ironic yet determined. Inside, Governor Sir Edward Gait, with the King’s portrait behind him, feels cornered, tapping a folder irritably. His old friend, Sir George, looks on defensively. Together they share a long history in India, arguing as friends from the same school and social class, even as the Governor feels the game isn't played fairly.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi sits pensive while Charlie observes him. A grin forms on Gandhi's face, but his mood remains remote. Gandhi's anger turns to a sigh, leaving Charlie stunned. Gandhi then speaks warmly, with purpose, handing Charlie some notes. Charlie, emotional, understands Gandhi's vulnerable smile. The packed courtroom grows restless as Gandhi sits in the dock. The magistrate notices Indian journalists, feeling alarmed. As Gandhi stands, chanting is heard outside. The magistrate is aware of the mob as chaos erupts with cheers. Gandhi exits, greeted by peasants' cheers. Meanwhile, Governor Sir Edward Gait feels cornered, surrounded by folders, discussing with Sir George, an old friend from school, about fairness in their shared duties.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: Gandhi, thoughtful and deep in reflection, continues to sit quietly, holding his place while Charlie takes a moment to observe him with intense curiosity. A faint, subtle grin emerges on Gandhi's face, yet his demeanor remains introspective, distant, and contemplative. As Gandhi lifts his gaze, there’s a flash of anger and unwavering determination in his eyes, which quickly dissolves into a sigh filled with resignation and hopelessness, leaving Charlie visibly taken aback and clearly hurt by the exchange. Gandhi adopts a more gentle approach, and in this transformation, Charlie gains a newfound understanding. With a smile that mixes warmth and underlying sadness, Gandhi begins to speak, his words infused with determined intent and trust, as one speaks to a cherished friend. From beneath the bedding, he retrieves a few worn, scratched notes and extends them to Charlie. He nods affirmatively, locking eyes with Charlie in a smile that conceals his vulnerabilities yet reciprocates the affection Charlie offers. The very English, very resolute Charlie struggles to maintain control over his emotions. The courtroom, filled to its capacity and buzzing with restlessness, holds Gandhi in the dock. The English magistrate, surveying the crowded courtroom, beckons his English clerk to approach him. With a frown, the magistrate notices from his vantage point the presence of two or three Indian journalists along with one European in the front row, an observation that causes him some unease. He signals the clerk to assume his position. As Gandhi stands, a hush falls over the courtroom, though the distant sound of chanting can still be heard from outside. The magistrate watches intently as journalists scribble notes, and the clerk nervously gulps. Fully aware of the throng outside, the magistrate glances around the courtroom, prompting the clerk to lower his focus to his notepad. The magistrate's eyes scan the far wall, the top of his desk, and his fidgeting hands, searching for an elusive answer, before he again focuses on the scene before him, along with the journalists' attentive gazes. With a quick wetting of his lips, the court erupts into chaos, filled with cheering and elation. Rising from his seat, the magistrate takes a moment to look around the bustling room before retreating to his chambers, while journalists hastily jot down every detail. Gandhi turns to exit the courtroom, descends the steps to the balcony, and is met with a loud, enthusiastic cheer from the gathered peasants below. As he smiles appreciatively down at them, he is momentarily taken aback by a sense of surprise and cautiousness, followed by heightened wariness upon hearing a comment that, though light in tone, carries a determined and even angry edge. Meanwhile, inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, finds himself feeling cornered for separate reasons. Behind him looms a prominent portrait of the King, while his desk is cluttered with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and a small pile of folded newspapers resting in one corner. Irritated, he taps one of the folders with his hand as Sir George looks on, his expression a mix of defensiveness and defiance. Being old friends from the same academic institutions and social circles, they have spent a considerable amount of time together in India, engaging in debates as friends who share similar foundational beliefs, even as the Governor senses a shift in the game’s fairness.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: Gandhi, immersed in profound thought and deep reflection, remains seated in silence, maintaining his composure while Charlie takes a moment to attentively observe him with a gaze filled with intense curiosity. A faint yet subtle grin gently spreads across Gandhi's face; however, his demeanor continues to be introspective, somewhat distant, and thoroughly contemplative. As Gandhi lifts his gaze, there emerges a flash of anger coupled with an unwavering sense of determination in his eyes—an intense expression that quickly transforms into a sigh laden with resignation and a profound sense of hopelessness, leaving Charlie visibly taken aback and clearly hurt by this poignant exchange. Gandhi deliberately adopts a more gentle approach, and through this transformation, Charlie acquires a newfound understanding. With a smile that conveys both warmth and a lingering, underlying sadness, Gandhi begins to speak, his words infused with determined intent and heartfelt trust, as one would speak to a cherished friend. From beneath the bedding, he carefully retrieves a few worn, scratched notes, extending them towards Charlie. He nods affirmatively, locking eyes with Charlie in a smile that, while concealing his vulnerabilities, reciprocates the sincere affection that Charlie offers. The very English, very resolute Charlie struggles visibly to maintain control over his emotions. The courtroom, filled to its capacity and buzzing with restlessness, holds Gandhi in the dock. The English magistrate, surveying the crowded courtroom with a discerning eye, beckons his English clerk to approach him. With a frown of concern, the magistrate notices, from his vantage point, the presence of two or three Indian journalists accompanied by one European in the front row, an observation that causes him a measure of unease. He discreetly signals the clerk to assume his position. As Gandhi stands, a hush descends over the courtroom, though the distant sound of chanting remains audible from outside. The magistrate watches with intensity as journalists diligently scribble notes, and the clerk nervously swallows hard. Fully aware of the throng outside, the magistrate glances around the courtroom, prompting the clerk to lower his focus to his notepad. The magistrate's eyes scan the far wall, the top of his desk, and his own fidgeting hands, as if searching for an elusive answer, before he again concentrates on the scene unfolding before him, along with the journalists’ attentive gazes. With a quick wetting of his lips, the court erupts into chaotic excitement, filled with collective cheering and elation. Rising from his seat, the magistrate takes a deliberate moment to survey the bustling room before retreating to his chambers, while journalists hastily jot down every detail of the events. Gandhi turns to exit the courtroom, descends the steps leading to the balcony, and is met with a loud, enthusiastic cheer from the gathered peasants below. As he smiles appreciatively down at them, he is momentarily taken aback by a sense of surprise and a cautiousness that quickly escalates into heightened wariness upon hearing a comment that, although light in tone, carries a determined and even angry edge. Meanwhile, inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, finds himself feeling cornered for entirely separate reasons. Behind him looms a prominent portrait of the King, while his desk is cluttered with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and a small pile of folded newspapers resting in one corner. Irritated, he taps one of the folders with his hand as Sir George looks on, his expression a blend of defensiveness and defiance. Being old friends from the same academic institutions and social circles, they have spent a considerable amount of time together in India, engaging in debates as friends who share similar foundational beliefs, even as the Governor senses a shift in the perceived fairness of the game.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi remains seated, his demeanor contemplative and introspective, as Charlie observes him closely, his gaze filled with curiosity and concern. Gradually, a subtle grin forms on Gandhi's face, a fleeting expression of warmth that does little to alter his otherwise reflective and distant mood. Gandhi raises his eyes, conveying a mixture of anger and determination, but this intense expression soon dissipates, giving way to a deep, hopeless sigh. This emotional shift leaves Charlie taken aback, visibly wounded by the change he perceives in Gandhi's demeanor. Sensing Charlie’s reaction, Gandhi softens his approach, allowing Charlie a moment of clarity and understanding. Gandhi then smiles, his expression a blend of warmth and underlying sadness, as he begins to speak with a tone of resolute intent and the implicit trust found in a profound friendship. From beneath the bedding, Gandhi retrieves a set of scratched notes, diligently collected, and extends them to Charlie, offering them with a nod that speaks volumes. His eyes meet Charlie’s, and his smile, though vulnerable, conveys an unspoken affection and mutual respect. Charlie, embodying the quintessential English resolve, valiantly strives to maintain control over his emotions, betraying them only slightly in his steadfast demeanor. Meanwhile, the courtroom is filled beyond capacity, the air thick with anticipation and restlessness as Gandhi takes his place in the dock. The English magistrate, overseeing the proceedings, surveys the room with a discerning eye, summoning his English clerk with a subtle gesture. A frown creases the magistrate's brow as his gaze lands on the front row, where two or three Indian journalists sit alongside a single European, a tableau that induces a brief moment of alarm. He signals the clerk to assume his position, an unspoken directive imbued with urgency. As Gandhi stands, a heavy silence envelops the courtroom, yet the distant sound of chanting from outside penetrates the stillness, a persistent reminder of the outside world’s presence. The magistrate’s eyes fixate on the journalists busily writing, while the clerk gulps nervously, fully aware of the charged atmosphere and the crowd gathered beyond the walls. The magistrate, his mind racing, finds himself searching the far wall, the surface of his desk, and his own trembling hands for a resolution, his gaze then returning to the journalists once more. With a nervous gesture, he moistens his lips, and as if on cue, the courtroom erupts into a cacophony of cheers and exuberant celebration. Rising from his seat, the magistrate takes a moment to absorb the scene, his eyes sweeping over the room before he withdraws to his chambers, leaving the journalists to furiously document the unfolding events. Gandhi, undeterred, turns to exit the courtroom, descending to the balcony where a resounding cheer rises from the multitude of peasants gathered below. He acknowledges them with a smile, his expression briefly shifting to one of surprise and caution as he discerns a sound that seems offhandedly ironic, yet carries an undercurrent of determination and anger. Inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, stands poised in his office, the portrait of the King prominently displayed behind him, symbolizing the weight of authority. He feels besieged by a different set of pressures, his desk cluttered with neatly stacked folders and a few haphazardly placed newspapers in one corner. Irritated, he taps one of the folders with his hand, seeking solace or an answer in the tactile gesture, while Sir George regards him with a mixture of defensiveness and defiance. The two men, bound by a shared history and social upbringing, engage in a tense dialogue, aware of their longstanding friendship but also of the underlying disagreements. Sir Edward harbors a sense of betrayal, perceiving that the accepted rules of their engagement have been subtly manipulated to his disadvantage.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: Gandhi remains seated, pensive, while Charlie observes him. Although Gandhi briefly grins, his mood stays distant. With a look of anger and determination, Gandhi's expression shifts to a hopeless sigh, leaving Charlie stunned and hurt. As Gandhi softens, Charlie gains understanding. Smiling warmly yet sadly, Gandhi speaks with purposeful determination and trust, handing Charlie some scratched notes retrieved from under the bedding. Gandhi's smile reflects vulnerability and affection, while Charlie, very English and steadfast, struggles to contain his emotions. In a packed and restless courtroom, Gandhi sits in the dock. The English magistrate, surveying the room, signals his clerk over, troubled by the presence of Indian journalists and one European in the front row. As Gandhi stands, the courtroom falls silent, but chanting from outside remains audible. The magistrate, aware of the crowd outside, searches for answers as the journalists write. Chaos erupts with cheering, prompting the magistrate to rise and head for his chambers. Gandhi departs the courtroom to a cheering crowd, smiling down at them with surprise and caution, reacting to something ironically yet determinedly spoken. Inside, Governor Sir Edward Gait, feeling cornered, irritably taps a folder amid a desk of identical ones and newspapers. Sir George, half defensive and defiant, shares a longstanding friendship with the Governor, both from the same school and social class, arguing as friends despite the Governor's sense of unfair play.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: Gandhi has remained seated, pensive, while Charlie studies him for a moment. Charlie, who is a British journalist known for his empathetic reporting on India's independence movement, notices a little grin appear on Gandhi's face, but his mood stays pensive and remote. Gandhi looks up with anger and determination, the same fiery resolve he famously displayed during the Salt March, which is then broken by a hopeless sigh, leaving Charlie stunned and obviously hurt. Gandhi proceeds more gently, and now Charlie understands. Gandhi smiles, showing warmth and sadness, then speaks with determined purposefulness and a friend's trust. He has taken some scratched notes from under the bedding, a traditional khadi cloth used by many Indians as a symbol of self-reliance against British textiles, and handed them to Charlie. He nods, meeting Charlie's eyes with a smile that shelters his vulnerability and returns his love. The very English, very steadfast Charlie, an Oxford graduate known for his stoic demeanor, fights to contain his emotions. The courtroom is packed to overflowing and restless as Gandhi sits in the dock, a pivotal trial that has drawn international attention. The English magistrate surveys the courtroom and signals his English clerk, who has recently been transferred from London, to him. The magistrate frowns, seeing the front row from his point of view with two or three Indian journalists and one European, which he receives with some alarm, aware of the political implications, and he indicates that the clerk take his place. Gandhi stands, and the courtroom is silent, but the sound of chanting outside, reminiscent of the protests that have swept across the country, is still audible. The magistrate stares as the journalists write and the clerk swallows, aware of the historic nature of the proceedings. The magistrate is only too aware of the mob outside, reminiscent of the crowd during the Jallianwala Bagh massacre, as he looks around the courtroom. The clerk lowers his eyes to his pad. The magistrate searches the distant wall, the top of his desk, and his twitching hands for an answer, then stares again, along with the journalists. The magistrate wets his lips, and the court explodes into chaos with cheering and delight. The magistrate rises, looks around the room, and heads for his chambers as the journalists scribble furiously, documenting the moment for newspapers around the world. Gandhi turns and starts out of the courtroom, steps down from the courtroom to the balcony, and a huge cheer comes up from the massed peasants below, echoing the sense of hope and revolution prevalent among the Indian population. As he smiles down at them, he is turned by surprise and caution, followed by even more caution on hearing something that sounds casually ironic but is determined, even angry, reminiscent of the rhetoric used by Indian freedom fighters. Inside, the Governor, Sir Edward Gait, who has been a key figure in British rule over India, with a portrait of the King prominent behind him symbolizing colonial power, feels cornered for different reasons while the desk is arrayed with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner. He taps one of the folders irritably with his hand as Sir George, a fellow colonial officer, looks at him, half defensive and half defiant. They are old friends from the same school and social class, both having attended Eton, who have been together a long time in India, arguing as friends who accept the same premises, although the Governor feels the game has not been played quite fairly.

test_cases.description: Gandhi has remained seated pensive while Charlie studies him for a moment. A little grin appears on Gandhi's face but his mood stays pensive and remote. Gandhi looks up with anger and determination which is then broken by a hopeless sigh leaving Charlie stunned and obviously hurt. Gandhi proceeds more gently and now Charlie understands. Gandhi smiles showing warmth and sadness then speaks with determined purposefulness and a friend's trust. He has taken some scratched notes from under the bedding and handed them to Charlie. The magistrate rises looks around the room and heads for his chambers as the journalists scribble furiously. Gandhi turns and starts out of the courtroom steps down from the courtroom to the balcony and a huge cheer comes up from the massed peasants below. As he smiles down at them he is turned by surprise and caution followed by even more caution on hearing something that sounds casually ironic but is determined even angry. Inside the Governor Sir Edward Gait with a portrait of the King prominent behind him feels cornered for different reasons while the desk is arrayed with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner. He taps one of the folders irritably with his hand as Sir George looks at him half defensive and half defiant. They are old friends from the same school and social class who have been together a long time in India arguing as friends who accept the same premises although the Governor feels the game has not been played quite fairly.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~80%)
test_cases.description: Gandhi has remained seated pensive while Charlie studies him for a moment. A little grin appears on Gandhi's face but his mood stays pensive and remote. Inside the Governor Sir Edward Gait with a portrait of the King prominent behind him feels cornered for different reasons while the desk is arrayed with several tall stacks of identically covered folders and some folded newspapers on one corner. He taps one of the folders irritably with his hand as Sir George looks at him half defensive and half defiant. They are old friends from the same school and social class who have been together a long time in India arguing as friends who accept the same premises although the Governor feels the game has not been played quite fairly.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: Elvis has remained hovering, bewildered, while Luna sketches him for a moment. A small frown emerges on Elvis's face, but his mood remains bewildered and detached. Elvis gazes up with joy and curiosity, which is then shattered by a triumphant laugh, leaving Luna amused and obviously delighted. Elvis advances more recklessly, and now Luna misunderstands. Elvis shrugs, expressing indifference and frustration, then gestures with distracted aimlessness and an enemy's caution. She has retrieved some polished marbles from under the couch and tossed them to Luna. She winks, meeting Luna's gaze with a frown that conceals her invincibility and rejects her affection. The very French, very erratic Luna grapples to unleash her indifference. The circus tent is crammed to suffocating and jittery as Elvis floats in the net. The French acrobat scans the circus tent and gestures his French mime to him. The acrobat grins, observing the back row from his perspective with two or three penguin spectators and one extraterrestrial, which he perceives with some relief, and he signals that the mime take his position. Elvis leaps, and the circus tent is noisy, but the sound of drumming outside is still apparent. The acrobat stares as the spectators dance and the mime sings. The acrobat is only too ignorant of the gathering outside as he glances around the circus tent. The mime lifts his feet to his drum. The acrobat scans the distant ceiling, the bottom of his chair, and his steady feet for a question, then grins again, along with the spectators. The acrobat clenches his fists, and the tent implodes into silence with sobbing and despair. The acrobat falls, gazes around the space, and heads for his trailer as the spectators sketch lazily. Elvis spins and hops out of the circus tent, floats up from the circus tent to the rooftop, and a small murmur rises up from the dispersed performers above. As he frowns up at them, he is startled by confidence and recklessness, followed by even more recklessness upon hearing something that sounds eagerly sincere but is confused, even joyous. Outside, the Jester, Lord Reginald Kite, with a mural of the Queen dominant before him, feels liberated for similar reasons while the chair is stacked with several short towers of differently colored feathers and some flattened cupcakes on one corner. He spins one of the feathers joyfully with his foot as Lady Beatrice glances at him, half merry and half jubilant. They are old enemies from the same planet and different time zones who have drifted apart a short time in Greece, laughing as enemies who ignore the same conclusions, although the Jester believes the puzzle has not been solved quite accurately.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: Gandhi remains seated, his expression a mix of pensiveness and determination, until broken by a sigh of hopelessness, leaving Charlie stunned. Gandhi gently shares his thoughts, giving Charlie scratched notes with a smile that conveys vulnerability and trust. In a packed courtroom, Gandhi's presence is met with tension. The English magistrate shows unease at the diverse audience, especially journalists, and is aware of the chanting mob outside. As Gandhi stands, the courtroom erupts in chaos with cheers. Gandhi exits to a balcony, greeted by a massive cheer from peasants below. Meanwhile, Governor Sir Edward Gait, feeling cornered, discusses with Sir George, an old friend, over stacks of folders, highlighting their shared past but differing perspectives on fairness.
